reviewText:
Product received for free

Survive in Space
DISCLAIMER: I received this product for no cost for the purpose of reviewing.

The team at Just1337 must really love space and space themed games, as this is there 4th space game on Steam. Survive in Space is a 2D Space Shooter. The story is kind of interesting so I won't spoil it, but throughout the stages of of this game, you pilot a space fighter. You can choose between 5 initially, though I'm not sure if more unlock as you continue to play. Each ship has a set passive abilities that are different from the other ships, and you can choose a ship to cater to your playing style. You can also switch what ship you want to use before each stage. You have a basic attack and 2 other skills you can use in combat, and after each stage your character receives experience as well the ship that you are using. When your ship levels up you can assign more passive abilities to it, and the same applies to your character.

The combat itself puts you in a space battlefield for each stage. You are tasked with taking down all enemy ships as they appear on your screen with your various abilities to complete the stage. You can manage the difficulty of each battle from the classic presets of Easy
date: Medium & Hard" as well as choose to add more asteroids (which pose as flying obstacles) as well increasing the amount of enemies you have to defeat. Of course the more difficult you make it for yourself
recommended: the more experience your will accumulate. The game can be a bit bullet hell-y at times
hoursPlayed:
and there are boss battles at certain stages.

--------

Graphics: 7 / 10

The art style might be subjective. It's a 2D western animeish design for the characters
voteText: which isn't something I tend to enjoy but I could see how a lot of people would appreciate it. The back drop for the battles is decent
helpfulPercent: though I feel it does get a bit repetitive after awhile
votesHelpful: although I haven't played all the stages to know if it's different later on. The animations are also decent
votesTotal:
and the combat effects as well as the menus are designed pretty nicely. There shouldn't be any problems running the title on any graphics card or CPU as it is not a demanding title.

--------

Sound: 8 / 10

Everyone has different tastes in music
votesFunny: but I feel like anyone who can enjoy EDM music; this title has a nice soundtrack for you. I personally enjoy the music in this game
commentsCount: it reminds me a lot of their other title Neon Space
column16: which I believe some of the music is also from. I noticed in the music interface that they have various types of EDM styles like: Drumbass
column19: and as someone who enjoys this type of music
column20:
I would rate it pretty highly. There is also options to skip to the next track as well as shuffle and repeat features. The in-game and combat sound effects are also decent and surprisingly didn't feel repetitive. There is also some voice acting within the game which is also very subjective.

--------

Mechanics: 7 / 10

For a title like this
column21: the mechanics are pretty solid. You have your basic attack
column22: and your 2 other skills. You more around with either a controller
column25: and shoot down enemies on your screen while avoiding their fire. Unlike some shooters
column26: you also have the option of flipping your ship and shooting in the opposite direction. I do find it a tad frustrating not being able to shoot up and down at times
column27: though I feel the controls might be too messy if something like that was implemented. You can switch between two different modes while playing
column29: which both offer benefits and disadvantages. The enemy variety is pretty good
column30:
there's quite a few different looking enemy ships with different abilities. You can upgrade your ship as well as your character with experience at the end of each battle as well as toggle the difficulty level.

--------

Final Personal Remarks

I think Survive in Space is a good title for beginners who want to get into 2D shooters. It's not as intense as some bullet hells but it can give you some rush and satisfaction when you're able to take down all the enemies. The art style isn't  something I personally enjoy but I do like the soundtrack and how you can upgrade your ships as well as your character. The story seems interesting but also kind of clich√©
column31: but I see it hooking a lot of people. In my experience with playing the game
column32: I preferred to stay in attack mode rather than defense mode. It's a bit riskier when you take a hit because you take more damage in addition to having your health points already lowered
column33: but you deal a lot more damage
column34: and it's easier to take out enemies.\n\nThanks to the Devs for giving me the opportunity to review the game
column35: as well as anyone who took this review into consideration

reviewText:
Product received for free

Provided by Giveaways Reborn
Survive in Space is a 2D space shooter, based around Sasaki, who lives in a galaxy that has been taken over by an evil people known as The Chronicles." Sasaki discovers the truth about The Chronicles and the history of his people
date: and must fight to earn redemption.\n\nPresentationIn game
hoursPlayed: and all the art compliments each other perfectly
voteText: making this game a feast for the eyes. Outside of the gameplay
votesHelpful: the graphics seem to be lacking.\n\nThe main menu's art is quite nice
votesTotal: with an animated picture of Sasaki on a seemingly deserted planet. The graphical design of the actual menu part
commentsCount: leaves much to be desired. While when the player hovers over an option
column16: the menu fits with the aesthetic of the game
column17: when the player is not hovering over the menu options
column18: they are just gray boxes with a font closely akin to Arial. This font is used throughout the game
column19: and it really draws away from the rest of the game's aesthetic.\n\nThe art style in the cutscenes is extremely unpolished compared with the rest of the game
column20: even to the point of looking unfinished at times. The voice acting in these cutscenes is very much a mixed bag. The narrator and the "servant of darkness" are both voiced extremely well
column23: is not. The voice actor sounds like he is reading a story to a kindergarten class
column24: and manages to do it with no emotion. Any emotion given to Sasaki's character through the voice acting seems very forced.\n\nThe music
column26: does not really fit in with the atmosphere of the game at points. The player can also add their own music
column27: as long as it is in .wav or .ogg format.\n\nInterface/ControlsThe user interface is generally very easy to use. The only major problem with it is that to access the upgrade and ship select screen
column28: the player has to leave the level select screen to go to the main menu
column29: where they must select the "Upgrades" option. A casual player who has never played this game before might totally miss it
column30: as it is not mentioned in any tutorial
column31: and try and get through some of the harder levels without any upgrades
column32: or without realizing there were other ships in the game.\n\nThe controls are quite comfortable and make sense. On a keyboard
column33: the game uses the MOBA system for attacks
column38: while on a controller it uses the regular buttons.\n\nPlotThe game follows Sasaki as he fights The Chronicles. He has the truth about The Chronicles revealed to him by an ancient writing of some sort
column39: and is then seduced by a "servant of darkness
column40:
who is also seeking vengeance against The Chronicles.

The script is poorly written, with Sasaki's emotions or thoughts only ever being revealed through him saying directly what they are. It does not flow well, with the characters often speaking in short or fragmented sentences, and going out of the way to make sure that the audience does not have to infer anything.

GameplayThe game tries to be a sort of bullet hell space shooter, but fails in that it is too slow paced. This becomes apparent at the very beginning, when the first enemy to spawn takes eight hits with the base weapon to kill. This does not change as the player levels up - at level one, that enemy takes eight hits, at level five it takes the same.

Ther is a large variety of ships for the player to chose from, each having its own advantages and disadvantages. The only problem with this is that there is no indication of this capability from the level select screen or the main menu. To change ships, the player has to go to the main menu and select Upgrades
column41: then go to the Shipyard" tab.\n\nThe player is given three weapons - the basic weapon
column43: and homing missiles. The basic weapon is able to be fired every tenth of a second or so
column44: and the other weapons take a few seconds to recharge
column45: which can be upgraded to be less. The basic weapon is a machine gun which does about two damage to an enemy. The laser is a solid laser beam which does more
column48: homing missiles. They do a ridiculous amount of damage
column49: but take a while to recharge.\n\nThe player is also given a "super mode" upon pressing R
column50: that makes the players attacks more powerful
column51: but moves the ship's shields farther away
column52: rendering it more vulnerable to attack.\n\nThe player's ship can only shoot in two directions: left and right. This
column53: coupled with the fact that the ship moves quite slowly
column54: makes defeating enemies a chore sometimes. The player's ship also cant move to the very top or very bottom of the screen
column55: rendering enemies in certain positions unreachable.\n\nReplayabilityAfter completing the 50 levels with the game
column56: the player can continue leveling up indefinitely
column57: playing through those 50 levels again and again
column58: eventually becoming ridiculously overpowered.\n\nConclusionSurvive in Space
column60: is plagued with a myriad of problems
column61:
chief among those being the slow pace and a lack of general polish.

reviewText:
The is the fourth 2d space game that Just1337 released in the last year or so and I have to say that they are improving dramatically with every new installment.

Survive in Space is actually worth checking out, especially if you find it on sale and is actually a lot more polished than their previous games.

+responsive controls
+various difficulty modes
+fun bullet hole shooter
+RPG progression
+tons of upgrades and ships to master

-voice over is so so
-music may not suit the game well
-can get repetitive with time, especially if you've beaten the game

Full review here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rWVqTAAq0qk

reviewText:
Product received for free

A Space Action Shooter / Shoot 'Em Uphttps://youtu.be/1q-fW9tC7OQ
+ Fantastic relaxing soundtrack filled with Electronic, Trance, House, Trap, and Dubstep that fits very well with the space action theme. You also have full control to switch the songs at any time during the game.
+ Visually the game looks great with very bright colorful neon ships, bullets, and explosions along with some great looking outerspace backgrounds.
+ A unique mechanic where you can turn your ship left or right, so basically you are fighting waves of enemies that appear on both sides of the screen and generally stay in the center.
+ Upgrade / experience system, you can upgrade each of your weapons along a separate skill tree. You have player upgrades to increase your damage, shields, evasion, etc. And finally there are 5 ships to choose from that you can essentially level as you play to gain additional perks .
+ Great difficulty settings  / modifiers, to gain additional experience you can turn up the difficulty OR you can set modifiers to make the game more challenging such as more enemies, asteroids, and planetary fortresses" which will send a few planets at you during the mission which have rocket launching turrets on them.
+ Challenging bosses which have a variety of unique abilities and movements to really keep things entertaining every 10 levels.
+ A surprising amount of voice acted cutscenes which you don't normally see in games of this genre.

- The story is a bit confusing to fully understand
- The voice acting / dialogue felt a bit forced at times
date: but as an indie project it's pretty easy to look past that\n- Even though there's 5 ships
recommended: you only have 4 abilities that you will be using repetitively throughout the 50 missions. It would have been nice if each ship had unique abilities to mix things up a bit."

reviewText:
Product received for free

Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a Casual space shooting game.


Interface/Menu/Settings
There is many Resolution Sizes.
You can change the Music Volume with a slidebar.
You can change the Sound Volume with a slidebar.
You can change the Voice Volume with a slidebar.
You can play Fullscreen and windowed mode.
There are many Languages.
You are able to change controls on your keyboard.

About the game.
You are a spaceship and your task is to destroy enemy spaceships. They are a set of waves and enemies. You have to complete every wave and kill every enemy in order to complete a level. You are able to turn on extra modifiers to make your game harder but they grant you more experience. Experiences are needed to level up and upgrading ur ship and ability power. Playing on higher difficulty will only give you more experience. IT will not change the ammount of ships and waves. They remain the same. However they do more damage and will get more HP. You are able to switch between Stances. Offensive Stance is good for attacking, giving you more power and speed. But defensive stance is good if you need to regain health. They both have their upside and downside.

Different difficulties.
Different ship with different ship bonus effects.
Great artwork.
Graphics are alright.
Music is alright? You can add your own music.
NO OPTIONS DURING A LEVEL.
Many levels. including bosses and other things.
Fonts are a bit too small to see your HP and experience. (You can't change it)


Other things.
I lost track sometimes where my own ship was, because of the surrounding balls.


My Video Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W_Yf-QxhTEY

-------------------

I Give this game a 7/10
